title: Sotheby’s to Offer Francis Bacon’s ‘Pope’ on Behalf of Brooklyn Museum
text:
Text size

A rare painting of Francis Bacon’s Pope series is expected to fetch between $6 million and $8 million when it’s offered at Sotheby’s New York sale of contemporary art on Nov. 14.

One of the only six surviving works from the British artist’s “Tangier Paintings,” the work has been held in the Brooklyn Museum’s collection since 1981. Proceeds from the sale will be used to support the museum collection.

In the mid-1950s, Bacon (1909-1992) made long visits to Tangier, Morocco, where his lover Peter Lacy had moved. Bacon was particularly prolific while there, but he ultimately destroyed the majority of the paintings he created, according to Sotheby’s.

“Pope offers an exceedingly rare glimpse into Francis Bacon’s psychological state during a prolific but ultimately tortured time in his life and career,” Grégoire Billault, head of Sotheby’s contemporary art department in New York and former researcher for The Estate of Francis Bacon, said in a statement.

While Tangier represented the artist’s first travels outside of Europe, and the promise of an open life with Lacy, their relationship proved volatile and violent, “which found expression in Bacon’s anguished Popes of the period—of which precious few survive,” Billault said.

The painting offered for sale was gifted to the Brooklyn Museum by Olga H. Knoepke, an American collector and a pioneering businesswoman. She purchased it in 1967 from the legendary Swiss dealer Jan Krugier, who himself acquired the painting from Bacon’s friend Nicolas Brusilowski, according to Sotheby’s.

The painting will be available for public viewing at Sotheby’s New York galleries starting Nov. 1.

Previously, only two of the six surviving Tangier Paintings have ever appeared at auction. The most recent—another Pope—was sold at Sotheby’s Paris for $7.3 million in 2008. A small head-and-shoulders portrait of Bacon’s Screaming Pope from the collection of Richard E. Lang and Jane Lang Davis fetched $50.4 million in Sotheby’s evening sale of contemporary art earlier this year in May.
